title: Impacts of Insurance on Colorectal Cancer Mortality: Insights from the National Inpatient Sample
text:
Reference Papers:

Akinyemiju et al. 2016
Galoosian et al. 2019

Study Objective: Examine the impact of healthcare insurance on in-hospital mortality, length of stay, and inflation adjusted charges among inpatient admissions with colorectal cancer (CRC).
Data Source: Cross-sectional analysis of the National Inpatient Sample (NIS) from 2018 to 2020.
Patient Selection: Included all inpatient admissions diagnosed with CRC.
Insurance Categories:

Private
Medicaid
Medicare
Other

Primary Outcomes:

In-hospital all-cause mortality
Total hospital length of stay (days)
Total charge, inflation adjusted to 2020 ($) [adjusted to 2020 dollars, using CPI data by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics]

Statistical Analysis: Multiple logistic and linear regression to determine the independent association of insurance categories with in-hospital mortality, length of stay, and inflation-adjusted total charge, respectively, adjusted for:

Demographics: Age, gender, race, residential income, residential region.
Medical History: Cancer metastasis.
Comorbidities: Charlson comorbidity index.

Software: All analyses were performed using R Version 4.4.1 (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria)
